What’s new?!

  • May 4, 2020: Solve Dynamic Rational Inattention Problems in milliseconds using the new DRIPs package.
    • Documentation, GitHub, Replication of Mackowiack Wiederholt (2009), Replication of Sims (2011)
  • April 10, 2020: New working paper on “A Model of Costly Recall”.
  • April 8, 2020: An interactive set of Jupyter notebooks for solving LQG Dynamic Rational Inattention Problems in Julia.
    • Launch binder

Publications

  • “Inflation Targeting Does Not Anchor Inflation Expectations: Evidence from Firms in New Zealand” (with Saten Kumar, Olivier Coibion, and Yuriy Gorodnichenko). Brookings Papers on Economic Activity 2015(Fall), 151-225.
    • PDF, NBER, Data and Replication Files
    • in media: VoxEU, Financial Times, Washington Post, Bloomberg, New Zealand Herald, CFO, Week

Working Papers

  • “A Model of Costly Recall” (with Spencer Kwon and Yueran Ma). This version: April 2020.
  • “Strategic Inattention, Inflation Dynamics and the Non-Neutrality of Money” This version: March 2020.
    • in media: Bloomberg
  • “Dynamic Rational Inattention and the Phillips Curve” (with Choongryul Yang). This version: November 2019.
    • Julia Package for Solving Dynamic Rational Inattention Problems (DRIPs)
    • Matlab Solver for Dynamic Rational Inattention Problems
    • An interactive Jupyter notebook for solving Dynamic Rational Inattention Models in Julia
  • “Endogenous Firm Competition and Cyclicality of Markups” This version: December 2019. Other versions: Dallas Fed. Revise and Resubmit at Review of Economics and Statistics.

    • Slides
  • “Rationally Confused: On the Aggregate Implications of Information Provision Policies” (with Miguel Acosta).
    • Slides
